title: Gilt prices fall sharply after UK inflation ticks up unexpectedly
text:

Tue, Aug 18, 2015, 18:30 BST - UK Markets closed Gilt prices fall sharply after UK inflation ticks up unexpectedly Reuters - UK Focus â€“ 1 hour 31 minutes ago UBGXF 0.00 
LONDON, Aug 18 (Reuters) - Gilt prices fell sharply on Tuesday after stronger-than-expected inflation data boosted bets the Bank of England will hike interest rates early next year, albeit only slightly. 
Thirty-year British bond yields touched their highest level since Aug. 6 at 2.578 percent after the inflation figures, which showed consumer prices inched up 0.1 percent, compared with no change expected by economists. 
Short-dated gilt yields, particularly sensitive to changes in rate expectations, were also up sharply. 
The data helped sterling power to its strongest in 7-1/2 years against a trade-weighted basket of currencies. 
Short sterling futures fell, particularly for the late-2016 and 2017 contracts, indicating a slightly steeper rate path or more aggressive tightening cycle. 
However, this cancelled out similar-sized moves in the opposite direction on Monday, effectively leaving the outlook for interest rates little changed since the start of the week. 
RBS (LSE: RBS.L - news ) rates strategist Simon Peck said the market now priced in an around 62 percent probability of an interest rate hike in February, compared with around 55 percent in early trading. A rate hike for May was fully priced in by the market. 
"I don't think the market's really re-assessed its view in terms of the timing of the first interest rate move, it's longer dated bonds that have felt the pressure of today's price action," said Peck. 
Ten-year British bond yields hit the day's high at 1.89 percent, widening the spread versus equivalent German bonds to 124.4 basis points - its highest in two weeks. 
The 10-year yield was last up 6 basis points on the day at 1.88 percent.
